##Why does $\dfrac4{10}\times4=2\times\dfrac{8}{10}$ ?

$\begin{align}
&\dfrac4{10}\times\blueD4\\\\
&=\dfrac4{10}\times(\blueD2\times\blueD2)\\\\
&=(\dfrac4{10}\times\blueD2)\times\blueD2\\\\
&= \dfrac{\blueD{8}}{10}\times\blueD2\\\\
&=2\dfrac{8}{10}
\end{align}$

We can also visualize the expressions:



[[☃ image 1]]

The expressions $\dfrac{4}{10}\times4$ and $2\dfrac{8}{10}$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.

The bottom bar is aligned with the top bar and is divided into 2 equal parts with each part labeled eight-tenths. Below the bars is a number line labeled zero-tenths to sixteen-tenths with tick marks at every one-tenth unit and labels every eight-tenths unit. Above the number line, there are labels every four-tenths unit. There is a dot at sixteen-tenths, which lines up with the end of both fraction bars.

##Why does $\dfrac4{10}\times4=\dfrac2{10}\times8$ ?

$\begin{align}
&\quad {\maroonD{\dfrac4{10}}}\times4\\\\
&=\dfrac{\maroonD2\times\maroonD2}{10}\times4\\\\
&=\dfrac2{10}\times(\maroonD2\times4)\\\\
&=\dfrac2{10}\times\maroonD8
\end{align}$

We can also visualize the expressions:


[[☃ image 1]]

The expressions $\dfrac{4}{10}\times4$ and $ \dfrac2{10}\times8$ are on the same point on the number line, so they are equivalent.
